replies.author: @trishfitzpatrick2066
@117Industries
replies.text:
@trishfitzpatrick2066 Thanks for the feedback, truly. 

I think it‚Äôs an almost impossible moral pinch-point: on the one hand we have defective narcissists, but on the other hand they were literally engineered that way. And most of the people who break free of the Matrix seem to have either had extremely loving parents, if not received discipline and had a work-ethic instilled into them by alternative means. Call it wimpy if you will, but terminating a bunch of people for having been born into a bad start seems almost callously evil. But then we have the situation we have, and only limited time with which to solve serious problems and promote radical change. Ergo, the reasonable compromise would seem to be to force these people out of positions which they do not deserve, are not entitled to, and haven‚Äôt the means to retain, let alone effectively make use of. Obviously they‚Äôll kick and moan, but that‚Äôs irrelevant. They will literally be better off for it, as will their progeny. 

Community-building is therefore a good idea on the local level‚Äî getting people working together and for themselves, while developing real, non-Matrix life skills so they‚Äôre capable of fending for themselves. I think that will work because ultimately the pushback against the machine‚Äôs collapse is just an expression of impotence. But if you empower them, they‚Äôll *choose* to do it, because the trialling process of developing that empowerment will *show* them how liberating and rewarding it is. 

In the end, everyone *can* win. It will be ridiculously hard, but it can be done (I‚Äôm sure of it). 

Better get mapping out strategies and grafting on my end‚Äî cashing my cheque where my mouth is haha.

@RyosukeTakahashiRX7 I do not have an internalized prejudice against my own sex. I can't speak for everyone else, but nowhere in my comment did I mention a specific sex. I've seen men and women complain about the gender pay gap. My point with the pay gap is that when people talk about it they only mention wages. No mention of the type of job, position, work hours, days worked vs days off, how much time is spent working overtime, how much time is spent on vacation, etc. All of these affect how much someone is paid.
 Men and women are different. We graviated towards different fields that align with our interests. Generally, women prefer fields such as social work, teaching, nursing and men generally prefer fields such as construction, plumbing, stem. There are outliers, of course, but if you were to look at the income of some of the jobs listed, the ones men typically work in pay more. It's not because employers have some agenda to pay women less than men, they don't. It's just that we happen to prefer work that doesn't have the same pay as others. Don't know how that was seen as misogynistic?

replies.author: @Tommy1977777
replies.text:
All legit observations here. However, let me tell you about my average "Work day": 

In combat I would: 
Pull 23 hour days nonstop for two months consecutively. 30 mins of sleep, 30 mins of patrol prep/briefing then back out on the road.

Possible risks: IED, Ambush, full on Firefight, death, dismemberment. 
Pay: low. 
Food: terrible (tasted better due to bear starvation conditions) .
Respinsibilities: i was in charge of 30 people at one time. Pay, Food, ensure enough water was being consumed in hot climates, medical needs were met (which were minim even if severe in civilian perspective).
 You had to earn (literally) respect by proving you were worthy of it. It could be lost at any time thus making your job more difficult. 

This is just for starters. 

Once you get back to the civilian world, you start all over again at the bottom. 

I'd love this ladies job. I'd love an analyst's job. Why? 

To put it simply: these jobs are comfortable. No sweating. No getting shot at or conducting a night time raid after being awake for 36 hours. 
The education is the easy part.

replies.author: @SweatyFatGuy
replies.text:
@pressb its hard for me to remember my parents doing something for me, and not having to work on the farm. I was operating farm equipment at 8 years old, that was in 1977. I worked my ass off to buy my first car at 13, and everything after that with my parents taking most of what I earned, I got the scraps of my labor. I left the farm at 17. Enlisted at 19 after finding the job market to be absolute crap, even for someone who was a competent machinist and mechanic.

I turned 21 in June of 1990, while I was home on leave. Got back to my base, and I remember vividly waking up to AFN (armed forces network) saying Iraq has invaded Kuwait and congress is considering sending in Marines and Airborne divisions. By the 10th of August, I was working 12 to 14 hour nights, with no days off, waking up just as tired as when I fell asleep in my uniform. My job was all about airlift, and that war was almost entirely airlifted. 

I packed on so much muscle from the heavy lifting of that job, that my weight went from 210, to 190, back up to 230lbs and I was absolutely ripped. Any idea how hard it is to do laundry when you have no days off, work 14 hour days, and you still need to sleep? Nobody did it for us. Finding food meant taking MRE's off airplanes I worked, there was no time in my day to go get food, I was on the flight line for the entire 12 to 14 hours. If I didn't grab an MRE here and there I did not eat. I warmed them on the intake manifold of the vehicles I was operating so I didn't have to eat cold MREs.

At 34 my second war started, this time for the profit of politicians. Turns out you can't work like you did at 21 when you are 34. You're no longer indestructible. Joints on me started wearing out in 2003, knees, shoulders, elbows, hips.. been trashed and living with chronic pain ever since. Also got divorced in 2001,so I was having 71% of my gross pay taken from me and given to her. I was graciously allowed $100 a month to live on by my home state, so I got to eat once a day and slept in my car or on friend's couches.

In 2013 I got divorced again, and decided to buy some land so I could build a home for me, and a shop to rebuild old cars, which is what I do to stay busy. Nobody showed up to help for most of it, in 2015 I hired two guys to help me do 90% of the roof on the shop. I did everything else, cleared trees, prepped the foundation, poured the concrete, built the walls, wired it... Crippled 45 year old builds home/shop.

I've been rebuilding and repairing my vehicles since that first one in 1982, it is VERY rare anyone else does something to them. Mostly I have a shop check my alignments, everything else I do. I did the front brakes on my beater 2000 Silverado 4x4 last night, so simple to do and I used to make $500 doing it for other people.

I look down on people who cannot do things for themselves, and have to pay others to do it for them. I see them as inept, incapable, and lacking knowledge as well as skills. If I ever get so old I can't do things for myself, I am gonna check out on my terms. I doubt I will make it that far though, its not like I haven't been exposed to some really nasty stuff over the years.. chem weapons in the first war, burn pits in the second one, farm chemicals for the first 17 years of my life, all the stuff with cars and machines... I'm amazed I am still alive at 53 to be honest.

I've never had the luxury of wondering if I am spoiled, I have always been the man people come to for help, they do not come to help me. If I don't do it, it doesn't get done. Nothing is provided for me like the chick in this video... nothing. I go to the VA for health care and they compensate me for breaking me in my two wars, but I earned the hell out of it. We might be even if I live to 110.

replies.text: I'm trying to convince people to invest in a business I'm thinking about. You pay an amount monthly and you'll receive a prize in cash if a random event happens. But if the event is YOUR car crashing RANDOMLY, then everything is just fine! This is very important: it has to be random, because if we discover it isn't, we don't pay you. Insurance is the biggest marketing bullshit ever made. Now we have millions of elderly people who spent precious thousands of dollars in insurance, mostly because in many places you are legally required to buy insurance. I know it's a fictional comedy, but there's some truth to it.

replies.author: @assortmentofpillsbutneverb3756
@Shade7x
replies.text: @assortmentofpillsbutneverb3756 That's an interesting thought. Like a depressed person. Normally we'd look at someone in a rut like that and say "you know, you'd feel a lot better if you did something with your day". What's one to do when their job is to sit around doing nothing? Especially given that they need to keep up a facade of busyness and can't just sit there reading books or something. It becomes difficult to get out of bed in the morning.

replies.author: @assortmentofpillsbutneverb3756
replies.text:
@Shade7x yeah tbh 9 hours 5 days a week is way to long to fake being busy. You end building horrible habits and its not like you are not tired when its all said and done because it is still mentally and emotionally draining. Also add in the mania when you actually do get work and the addictions like quick glances at your phone, podcasts, working alone, and sedentary sitting positions. Its literally not much different than the cycles of depression or the vibe from Bob cratchet silently scribbing away in the cold under a scrooge that will cut or replace you whenever it benefits them.

This all not to say other types of work are better or easier, just to say they tend to work be more "heroic" and work along with what an active human body thinks it should do. Basically its the type of work that embodies live in a pod, own nothing, eat the bugs, and be happy about it

replies.author: @testtuber999
replies.text: @rdubayoo I actually would love a more competitive free market capitalism based system for US, but thats not possible in real world without accounting for real world issues of corruption, incompetence, and societal needs. Energy sector is great example in US. We allow boom and bust cycles in price of energy. I advocate for energy price stabalization, where we set base price for energy such as say $50-60 a barrel of oil that government will buy for x amount of units as agreed to if no other buyer is found. That would allow for stability in exploration drilling and combined with government backed loans or underwriting for capital expenditures could create a more reliable energy sector. Energy costs should be regulated within margins for US domestic strategy. Right now free market enetgy sucks and is causing these dramtic cost increases. As far as I am concerned if a country cant maintain cost controls for energy and inflation it is a failed country/government.

author: @catreecemacleod7556
text:
The thing I keep trying to point out to people, is that when someone like this acts like someone not putting a happy face in the cream of their coffee is the worst thing that has ever happened to them, they're not overreacting - it literally is the worst thing that has ever happened to them.

Humans have an interesting trait that they zero out gradually over time. Doesn't matter how awful or how amazing life is, it gets set to zero, this is the baseline normal for you, and you always want just a little bit more than whatever you have. This lets us tolerate the most horrific of conditions and get through them, and it also means no matter how comfortable we become, we still push to make things even better. Without this trait, we never would have left living in caves or mud huts, nor would we have survived harsh winters and famines.

At the same time, when you have people who actually have real hardship and they come into contact with those living in a plush fantasy world, the two do not get along.

replies.author: @Patrick-857
replies.text:
Terrible things have happened to me over my life, and I die a little inside and then laugh about it. I'm mostly just numb, apart from when the adrenaline kicks in, then I get a little high off it, even though I'm having part of my life dismantled before my eyes. 

That sounds bad, but you're right, we become used to whatever our existence is and set that be our zero.  My existence would be intolerable to all but a few people I know, yet I am mostly not concerned by it. I'm not all "poor me" the only reason I know what's happened to me is bad is because other people find it bad. For me it's a nothing. Physical suffering is harder to get used to, psychological suffering is solved by eating something good, drinking, watching something interesting or going to sleep.

replies.author: @RiskOfBaer
replies.text: You made it way too complicated, it's actually really simple. We always judge things in relation to one another, same goes for happiness or hardship. So yes, if you have a woman like this who have clearly lived a very posh life, your definition of hardship might be having to stay late at work because that's literally one of the worst things that have happened to you in recent memory. Meanwhile a person who's in debt, working backbreaking work 12 hours a day, having to deal with rising gas prices and food shortages WISHES his only problem would be having to stay late at work sometimes, that would actually be happiness in his eyes not hardship. Doesn't make it any less pathetic to be the kind of person who's unable to deal with what most of us consider to be an average day, but it's still good to understand at least how those people come to be.

author: @rciscon
text:
I've lived in the Chicago area my entire life. She is the "new normal" for young people from good families.
* She either lives in Lincoln Park (or another trendy north-side Chicago neighborhood) or in the suburbs with her parents. 
* Her entire life is currently safely separated from the people and neighborhoods that make Chicago such a dangerous place. This will probably change as the economy weakens and urban barbarism encroaches upon her "safe spaces".
* She talks about "Working in Tech" when her job has NOTHING to do with technology. She's in marketing and seemingly has little or no problem solving skills that are the root of actual work with technology.
* Remember, she works for LinkedIn, which is a wholly-owned subsidiary of Microsoft, an actual Tech Company. The company currently has a lot of money to burn, but that won't last forever.
* Her job, and most like it are indications of an economy that's "sitting fat and sassy"... unfortunately the forced move away from a fossil fuel based economy by the Biden administration is putting the economy into recession and jobs like these will be the first to go.

Hard Times Make Strong Men, Soft Times Make Weak Men. I think we've hit peak Weak Men and are heading back towards Hard Times.

replies.author: @KratostheThird
replies.text:
@CCovers1 You have to remember that the Greatest Generation (born 1901/1902 to roughly 1925 - 1927) was also molded by the Roaring Twenties (1920s). Crime was rampant. Many innocent people died. Chicago was the place for the Chicago Outfit (that still exists) and the likes of Al Capone. 1929 marked a horrific year for crime and the economy. The stock market crash in October of 1929 would lead into the Great Depression, which engulfed all of the 1930s. 

Even in entertainment media like Hollywood, you can tell that this generation did their utmost best to fight for the greater good. World War 2, without the contributions of the Greatest Generation, would of turned out completely different. 

It‚Äôs why I think entertainers like Jimmy Stewart, Henry Fonda and Orson Welles are far superior to the likes of what Hollywood is doing now. The Millennial and Zoomer generation is full of beta males. Just like what went on with the MeToo movement, these young women are having their way while the men are getting chastised. 

This young 22 year woman has done nothing. And yet she holds more social capital and influence than a majority of men. This entire system is weak, and we‚Äôre very much heading towards a complete economic collapse. 

Perhaps the Zoomers may turn out strong later in life. Right now, I don‚Äôt see that happening any time soon.

author: @blackbird8192
text: I'm a software engineer and I've worked at a few large corps like these, and can confirm this is definitely the culture. But as an engineer, you don't have the luxury of not doing your work, but lots of times you still end up in meetings for half the day or more, even when you're under a time crunch. When that happens you just have to work overtime to get it done on time. It's really hard to believe just how much productivity is lost due to unnecessary meetings when a slack convo wouldv'e sufficed.

replies.author: @magneric
replies.text: Or an email from management to your department on what needs to be done for the week

replies.author: @alexmckee4683
replies.text: Also a software engineer, I used to joke about getting my work done in 10 minute sessions between meetings, but it ceased to be a joke when the workload rose and rose while the number of mandatory meetings reached almost 100% of the week. I'd get to the office at 0800, have a stand-up at 0900, a different meeting each day at 0930, a strategy meeting at 1000, sometimes a meeting to discuss testing at 1100, half the devs would go for lunch about 1200 while the other half, myself included, preferred 1300. Senior engineers, myself included, were required for a meeting at 1400 most days, while one day that didn't have that meeting had a whole team meeting for 2 hours, usually cram a bit of work in about 1500, have to catch various stakeholders before 1600 as none of them stayed after that, cram in 30 minutes of work and then rush to get my train. Some days I couldn't even get into the office being the first to arrive and not being a key holder. Fridays were a complete write off as at 1500 there was a whole company "huddle", taking up the only spare hour in the day. Somehow I managed to do everything that I was assigned and more, but it was not at all easy to find the time.

replies.author: @reaperinsaltbrine5211
replies.text: @alexmckee4683 And everyone wonders why most moders software is crap :/

replies.author: @blackbird8192
replies.text: @alexmckee4683 oof, exactly. I genuinely think a lot of people in these companies don't realize that someone eventually has to do actual work for the product to ship on time (or at all), and, shockingly, THEIR meeting does NOT constitute actual work! I think this is probly one of many reasons for the launch failures of a lot of high profile projects and games.

replies.author: @alexmckee4683
replies.text: @blackbird8192 they don't value what the actual developers do. I got more salary from learning to put up with meetings and how to handle the people side of the industry than I ever did from learning to do actual productive work. It's sad, but I am not sure how it can change. Except perhaps if tech people stop selling out their companies to empty suits.

I actively try to avoid any meeting where my presence isn't absolutely mandatory, and even then, I try to see if I can log in through teams. replies.text: Most organizations do have an over-abundance of meetings, but as someone who‚Äôs been on both sides, it can be very frustrating to submit multiple tickets and emails to a project manager to get a simple fix implemented that I could do myself if I had the permissions or could explain in 10 minutes if I just got the chance to talk to the developer. This is notwithstanding the many cases when I truly am out of my depth and don‚Äôt know exactly how long a certain task is going to take.

replies.author: @frankjennings4489
replies.text: @SoloRenegade Next to nothing for the bottom line? Where do you think all the money comes from? Without marketing and sales, you don‚Äôt have a company. The overstaffed thing is real though. At smaller companies, the marketing team is understaffed and do the very hard work of getting a company off the ground when no one knows you exist. As the company gets larger though, it becomes more of an aristocratic circle-jerk where there is less and less work being done per person and more people having meetings to tell each other how brilliant they are. LinkedIn is so big that the advertising mostly sells itself. Marketing brings in more revenue around the edges, but is mostly about crafting a corporate image.

replies.author: @SoloRenegade
replies.text:
@frankjennings4489 Tell that to Tesla and SpaceX. A good business/product sells itself. For those with limited exposure, a selectively good team of productive and creative individuals will get it done. I can out market the products I make. They'll assign 40 marketing people to sell what we do, and they fail miserably at it every time. They just don't get how to sell what we're making/doing.

I think we are in agreement though.

replies.author: @frankjennings4489
replies.text: @SoloRenegade I don't think those completely sell themselves. Elon Musk is a brilliant marketer. It might be his best skill, but he is also a great salesperson and engineer, and each of those skills compound on each other. There are some products that are spontaneously found by the right people and shared among a certain community to the point that they become successful, but there are even more companies with a promising product that never see the light of day because they don't know how to bring it to market. Like you said, a select team of creative and hardworking people is the best thing for marketing. The problem is that as the organization grows, it becomes less and less efficient and the temptation by management is to put more resources into marketing i.e. hiring more people which  just makes the team slower than they were before. The way that a marketer moves up in their career is by "building a team" and hiring people underneath them, so there is an incentive to hire more people even if you don't need them. You could be the most brilliant media buyer or graphic designer in the world, but if you want your company to pay you more, you better hire people underneath you to do the work that you used to do, only worse, because managers and creative directors make the big bucks.

replies.author: @SoloRenegade
replies.text:
@frankjennings4489 best avoided by instead rewarding marketing people based upon sales. for every sale they can attribute to marketing, they get a commission.

But I think engineers should be rewarded for successful and popular products as well.

replies.author: @frankjennings4489
replies.text: @SoloRenegade That would really depend on the industry. In the consumer product space, branding efforts can take awhile to take effect and attribution systems are never perfect. A lot of good marketers would probably prefer that though, and there are agencies that operate on that model. Unfortunately, I think engineers aren't rewarded that way for some of the same reasons. Which features led to the product being popular? Who designed those features, and who is just trying to take credit? Ideally those questions would have clear answers and clear goals and payouts, but that is a lot of work to think through, and it's easier for HR to think of employees as a steady paycheck.

replies.author: @SoloRenegade
replies.text:
@frankjennings4489 "and who is just trying to take credit?" seen far too much of this. gotten to the point guys wont even share ideas in meetings. We file disclosures before sharing in meetings now. some people are basically just professional patent filers. They file up to 60 patents per year. That's a lot of paperwork to fill out and review, and meetings with layers, and models/images to make, meaning they aren't getting anything else done. They sit in meetings and listen to other people's ideas. Then turn around an file disclosures of other peoples' ideas right after the meeting. each patent filed is a multi thousand dollar reward to the engineer/s who filed it. Some of these guys are making up to $180k/yr just in patent awards, plus their base pay. And all those patents make them look good and they get promotions. but they are actually worthless engineers.

Guys in my team only file our own ideas, and add each other to the patents when we helped develop the idea in some way. Or if someone else doesn't care, we'll file it, but include them on the patent so they still get credit and the bonus. But our team is small and doesn't like the corporate ways, nor do we operate with corporate methods in our team.

replies.author: @blackbird8192
replies.text:
@SoloRenegade wow that's incredible! Personally I'm not a big fan of the current patent and copyright system, I get why it was created initially, but it's just too easily abused. I think many times it ends up stifling creativity and collaboration rather than incentivising it. 

For example, one big reason 3d printing was able to take off in the maker space a few years ago was because several big patents expired, how much sooner could it have become widespread and been further developed if patents weren't an issue? Was the patent holder doing as much to develop the tech and benefit people as the entire community could?

Also, for decades the big car and oil companies have been buying small, innovative electric car companies and then shutting them down to stifle any competition. Not developing it or releasing it to market to benefit humanity, just killing it so they wouldn't have any disruptive competition. And because those big car/oil companies now owned the electric car company's patents, no one else could release that tech to market either. The only reason electric cars are taking off now is cuz Musk refused to sell Tesla to them early on, and ended up forcing the car companies to release their own electric cars to stay relevant and/or reduce Tesla's market share and capital.

And I could go on, there's tons of other examples of these systems being abused too, so much so that it makes me think that having these patent and copyright laws does more harm to society than good. Maybe there's a better way to do it, but I dunno what it'd be.

replies.author: @SoloRenegade
replies.text: @blackbird8192 You get it. I have some ideas, but the easiest would be prohibiting selling patents (use it, otherwise it becomes public domain, not letting corporations buy up patents). Maybe a limit on development. if a patent is not being developed, it expires. only letting individual people hold patents, not businesses, etc. Depends upon how you implement it. shorter patent protection periods.

She's not working in tech.  She's working in marketing.

Tech involves 12-hour days of grinding code out to meet an artificial deadline.  Tech involves being woken up at 3am to deal with a downed system costing your company $100,000 per second.  Tech involves getting on a ladder and squeezing yourself into a tight spot over the ceiling tiles to pull cable. Tech involves knowing how to actually, you know....*do* stuff.

She probably looks down on the real tech guys.  I just hope LinkedIn is paying the tech guys better than $24/hour plus bonuses.

@davidjacobs8558 Not necessarily, an annual net profit of $1 wouldn't sustain a company, profitability doesn't always equal a viable business. The converse applies as well, for example solar farms are not profitable in a free market but people have made a lot of money in that space because its heavily subsidized (and given enormous tax credits their competitors don't get) by governments, as well as their competitors being heavily penalized by the same governments. 

A company could  always be *more* profitable by dropping wastes of space such as featured in the video. I know I'd be rather annoyed to learn as a shareholder of a company I invested in that I could've potentially made a bigger ROI, but instead they hired people like this.

When 75% of all management either adds zero value or is actively detrimental to the organization, every business school in the world should close their doors forever.

replies.author: @BlueGrimgrin
replies.text:
@Kspice9000 Empire building. Being the contact who co-ordinates with the outsourced marketing? That's essentially an administrative position. Being in charge of the marketing department? That's a management or executive position. Generally the more people you have working for you the more important you are/feel. Same basic psychology as to why famous people have entourages. 

Generally when trying to understand any system or organization you don't just want to look at what is good for the organization as a whole, you want to look at what the incentives are for the people who make up the organization. A well run organization is one that aligns those two as closely as possible. A failing organization allows them to drift apart.

replies.author: @alanlight7740
replies.text:
@kylekatarn5964 - I've even seen this kind of waste in a construction company. It was officially owned by a woman (who had inherited it from her father) so it was a "minority contractor" that got preference in bids so long as a majority of the workers were minorities.

So a little over half our workers were minorities. About half were one particular minority, of whom about a dozen actually worked. The rest mostly stood around, though occasionally they picked up a tool and messed something up. I'd work nights and on one job for a couple weeks we had three and a half people (because I would finish up my regular shift and then go and help out this other crew) and at least for those two weeks about 95% of that job was done by us and the other 5% by the 20+ guys working day shift.

From some things I heard it seems that our minority employees were paid more than those of us doing the work.

That company, to its credit, had some great engineers and some very competent field workers - and eventually they gave up their minority contractor status and stopped competing for those set aside jobs. Of course that necessitated a big layoff, after which the dozen minority workers that everyone knew were willing and able to work were brought back ... and the rest were not. Last I heard the company is doing well.

A majority of its reality was lost as a result of the industrial revolution. There was a time in America known as the frontier/wild west whereby immigrants from around the world were capable of settling into camps & towns and were allowed to set up their shops immediately upon arrival. Everyone worked for themselves back then. But this would come to an end when gold, oil and steam barons (and bankers) became too powerful and started purchasing and exploiting tons of land. In the early 1900s you could still easily set up shop which is what a lot of Itallian and Chinese immigrants did but after the great depression, things started slowing down and production went straight to the Chinese. Now all of the bankers and oil barons have loads of money and kept people down.

Today, this has reached an extreme level and now people have lost a sense of identity because they are not working for themself (and have no religion). Many Mexican immigrants in the US work their asses off and do have some independent businesses but the way businesses are treated is bullshit. Megacorporations on the other hand can get away with anything and don't pay their taxes.

The west was once a great place for freedom but now it has become a joke because of massive corporations who have too much power and money. It is a massive shame.

I went into this field with a mindset that I never wanted to be a tradesman and after 4 years my outlook has completely changed. 

Going into one of these silly tech monopolies was my dream from a younger age. Now my dream is to go into that field one day with the life experience I have after continuing to work hard and diversify my skills, and infiltrate it from within in my late 30s or 40s, put on an act to climb the rung enough to make decisions that can change the culture in these vile monopolistic tech companies and restore meritocracy and order. author: @bitwize
text: Can confirm, Google is like this. Oodles of free food, free gourmet coffee, nap pods, adult playroom decor. Most people carry their laptops around so they can work whenever. I was a contractor, and Google doesn't approve laptops for contractors, so I was tethered to my desk (figuratively speaking). I was also expected to get actual work done. The work was actually on one of the most beautiful code bases I'd ever seen on an enterprise project. Honestly, the best people there were the oldbies -- folks in their 50s and 60s who'd been around the industry a while and got acquihired. Google had figured out a good formula for getting the benefits of their skills and knowledge while mollycoddling the Nooglers. Of course, as the James Damore case discovery showed, mollycoddling has its downsides too, as there are people inside Google who identify as anime characters or plushies of anime characters (or both simultaneously) and will probably scream that their rights are being violated if they are not acknowledged as such.

replies.author: @GabeSweetMan
replies.text:
Same deal at Disney corporate. Full time employees get all the freebies and benefits while the 3rd party contractors do all the real work and are barred from enjoying any of the freebies sitting a foot away from them. It's the modern caste system.

I was lucky enough to land a full-time position for several years, but coming from a background of hard labor, I mostly (with exceptions for both castes) got along with the 3rd party contractors because we could swap stories about the times we almost died at our previous real jobs.

My preferred go to story is the time I narrowly avoided being buried under 3 tons of falling break pads in the car parts warehouse.

author: @Anamnesis
text:
The literary connection to the "Pleasure Island" scene from Pinocchio is alarming; all the youths are lured to an oasis of indulgence and never want to leave. While it can be argued that her compensation seems a lot (whether for her age or for the nonexistent work she's engaged in) it's certainly not that much in Chicago or NYC where money doesn't go far. You're already scraping by on six figures in these cities and can barely afford to save anything if you actually live in these areas where everything is overpriced. And that was before inflation. But most of these types don't mind living in tiny apartments so long as they look trendy and have an ever-increasing list of communal amenities.

This sort of collectivist zeitgeist is the same with these companies and their various work perks. Personal remuneration isn't prioritized, they sell people on shared experiences, amenities and privileges. Just as it's cheaper for companies to encourage/promote/reimburse abortions over maternity leave in order to retain their workforce, it's also cheaper for them to compensate the youths with catered food, luxury trinkets, on-site services, looser schedules, less work, etc. rather than compensating them with money. Because doing that would allow them enough agency to structure their own lives.

You can't pay rent with complimentary beverages and scented towels, but they're effective tools of indoctrination to make people feel valued. In reality, these companies can lower their overhead by providing perks and benefits (ranging from potato chips to private quiet rooms) rather than increasing their salaries. Tech companies build their campuses to be one part office, one part mixed commercial entity, and one part theme park, because they don't want employees to have a reason to go home.

This is a modernized system of passive debt bondage, not much different from the old system where laborers owed their soul to the company store, except here the employees are willfully engaged in it because the company store basically operates free of charge. The youths don't even know they're in a closed ecosystem where their personal agency, purchasing power, and ability to make a life for themselves independent from the company (or the state) is being eroded away ever so slowly. They're too wrapped up in a pampered utopia to even notice.

The money is made in other areas. License contracts, software use, support and maintenance contracts etc.
The thing about multinational tech companies that have been around for a few decades is that they tend to make so much money just by the nature of the business that bloat, waste and inefficiency seems to come with the territory. Millions pumped into projects and man hours of development that ultimately go nowhere, non essential roles/jobs, keeping employees happy by adopting standards other companies set to avoid personnel turnover etc.
Think of Facebook. Enough money to buy the solar system, how many projects, r&d, human resources roles etc that don't directly to contribute to profits? A lot üòÖ

These companies hit it big with a certain gimmick or software that makes them money... Then are on easy street unless their shares or profits get majorly tanked for whatever reason.

author: @wge621
text:
I worked at facebook, amazon, and a gaming company. Amazon was nothing like this - they have massive inefficiencies and tons of internal competition so everyone has to work incredibly hard because stuff is just stitched together poorly internally. you also don't get any freebies aside from.. powdered apple cider ü§Æ but if there's an email chain called "Vultures" where you can have the pickings of food left over from bigger meetings

facebook though... jeez. it was worse than this video. and by worse I mean.. better? the san francisco campus has a GIANT courtyard.. actually it's more like a tiny town with free ice cream/sweet shop, BBQ restaurant, salad restaurant, indian food, and a few others to boot. you could get as many free headphones/keyboards/ other tech goodies out of vending machines. you didn't do any work, it was all about who you knew and sucking up because they had so much money that every individual did basically nothing besides eat food and drink coffee, wander around the beautiful campus.

I do miss it though. it's just not work

oh and the point about "it's no wonder these places are a hot bed for social justice warriors because your life is so hollow and all your comforts provided to you" that you have nothing else to do. so true. Ironically, facebook was the only time I experienced true sexism (by another woman in senior management), where I was essentially fired for being "too direct in emails" (actual quote), but told to train others to reach my level of proficiency (because I actually tried and gave a shit about my job, fuck me right!) before letting me go. it's all about saying the right things publicly and then screwing over people privately/having no regard for them because your own image matters more than anything else.

replies.author: @wge621
replies.text: MikeProductions1000 that's just because of the Norwegian paradox. You don't see the disparity in developing nations. But when get to choose what they want to do and aren't really struggling, they'll choose traditionally feminine roles at a higher rate

replies.author: @wge621
replies.text:
‚Äã@redact3d8472 not exactly, but I was training quite a few folks who were performing objectively worse than me, some were just flat out bad. but again, performance didn't matter there, at least not for most roles. 

I was initially told I "offended a thought leader". I asked who it was and they said "we can't tell you." I asked what I said and they said "we can't tell you." I asked how I was supposed to solve a problem that apparently occurred months ago and I have no context on, and they said they couldn't help me. it was a very weird gaslighting experience.

replies.author: @wge621
replies.text: @SJ amazing. Loved it. It did turn quite leftist at the end of my time though. But it was still so much fun working there (and I did do actual work and even got help to make a big career change). The political stuff could be ignored if you wanted to and enduring that was worth it for everything else -- good perks but you weren't completely spoiled or told to do inane shit all day. Gaming companies tend to skew male which I appreciated (although I'm a woman). You could literally play games at work, people were very chill and had a good sense of humor (for the most part). Still stay in touch with most of my friends I made there, almost two years after leaving

replies.text:
Depends. In a capitalistic society, a company run this way will eventually meet a competitor that will be able to run on a fraction of the employees that LinkedIn appears to need and a fraction of the cost. LinkedIn will either start firing and making these people put in a day's work or it will go bankrupt. 

However, these social media companies seem to have an arrangement with the government that the government will keep out any competition by turning a blind eye to any obvious monopolistic actions by social media and by making them impossible to be sued. In exchange, the social media companies censor what the government wants.

If this lasts then that woman will be drinking Chai lattes for the rest of her working career until she retires at 45 with 10 million dollars.

replies.author: @inquisitorwalmarius6650
replies.text:
@117Industries I do find it sad, very sad the older I get. And I would say that the only purpose the sex drive have, would be to sire offspring that the rest of your lifetime would be turning around to nurture and protect. But sex drive does affect behaviour too, which we are still getting a better understanding of. 

I find the complexity of the human nature and behaviours hard to understand, am I doing this because unlike it or am I doing it because my instincts tells me this is what is needed to fulfil one of the purposes of being a human?

At the same time I think the only purpose for humans are what they decide their purpose are, that it is not decided in advance, which makes it all more vexing. 

Until puberty, boys and girls doesnt really have the same outlook on sex as the concept arent important for their current state, thus they havent had the biological/psychological triggers set in yet, but then the hormones start to surge in uncontrollable amounts and we see the new behaviours appear. But over time for most it diminishes again after a few decades. Thus showing at least the period of time where the individual must act to secure the future of their own purpose or forfeit it. 

But still the purpose of sex and the sexdrive would seem to both be the continuation of Genes and spreading them. On the other hand it is not easy thus we strive to perform to attract a mate to do the business with. But over time there happens a shift, either you get offspring and most nurture them for the future both theirs and your own, but some individuals finds purpose in creating things instead, which usually would be done to (by nature) to attract a mate, building a dwelling, hunting or making useful tools or pleasant artworks, but instead because they get the same feeling of contentment and pleasure from those tasks or obtaining those skills for them selves, which maybe are more directed by logos than pathos. I may be wrong and I am feeling like I have strayed away from what I initially where trying to say. I am now confused and need a small break. Mind are overloading.

@chad_bro_chill Definitely! This is pretty much how I feel. A lot of "skeptics" claim to be, but are what I jokingly refer to as SINOs! (Skeptics In Name Only ;) ) A true skeptic applies that to everything, questions the validity of any assertion made by someone else, whether they be speaking from a position of authority or not.

I'm not necessarily full-blown agnostic atheist, but definitely at the very least agnostic theist. I don't think life, the universe, and everything just sprung up on its own, but it's impossible to know with our current knowledge and technology, whether that was a being of higher power or not. At the same time what we may see as a godly being just may be something we aren't able to fully comprehend... That aside, I honestly love religion and hearing/learning about it. I find it so fascinating that humans came up with ways to explain what they didn't understand and codify morals in such a way as to pass them on to future generations via cautionary tales and such. Obviously there's a lot of fantastical spins to things, but the core morals stand the test of time.

replies.author: @bakerboat4572
replies.text: @chad_bro_chill The latter type of atheist that you describe are actually anti-theists. Concurrently, I have almost never found a 'truly' atheist person speaking on religious matter.

text:
17:21 As a code monkey in corporate America... THANK YOU CARL! I feel so incredibly underappreciated for the amount of work I put into my projects. I've noticed on many, many occasions that my colleagues in more... female-oriented departments, they largely start their days later, will be doing housework during meetings and become generally upset when you ask them to review your work before presenting them with a "final product."

I've been at it for three years now. My only solace is that I get to work from home.

replies.author: @Mocha.
replies.text: I have been hired a contractor by Google and it is absolutely disgusting the way you get treated as an outsider and how much higher the expectations are. The top 5% engineers + contractors at Google easily do 99% of the work. You get thrown into meetings with arrogant women and rich trust fund boys that tell you what to do while knowing jack shit about engineering or system design. You can solve their issues, but are not considered for interview or hire. They rather do endless diversity hiring and recruit from their own caste of people so they can continue to pretend to be doing important work with each other.

replies.author: @farsidesc4044
replies.text:
@Mocha. My company started to heavily invest in diversity hiring. I wish I could call it anything else, but they explicitly said they were doing this.

We've let go 100% of the diversity hires thus  far. They were incredibly out of their league and depended on me to do the most menial of tasks (I'm a systems engineer, not your local Helpdesk).

The worst part, is that at least one of the diversity hires were fired for impropriety.

inb4 "uR rAcIsT": My boss is black and he's the best damn employee in my chain of command. It's never been about skin color; it's always been about competence.

replies.author: @notorious_raptor
replies.text: A female code monkey here. My boss just tells me he wants and I code it. Very little oversight. No hand holding. I hate meetings because I can't get more done, and I do work all day except during lunch, bathroom breaks, and the occasional coffee. And I love it. I wish I got paid more (started at 49k and am now at 69k after 3 years) but I love the satisfaction of creating software with a beautiful code base. But it really hurts me that these women state they work in tech. No, they don't. They work at a tech company. It's massively different. I work at an engineering firm, but that doesn't mean I do engineering. I got my degree in Computer Science. I do software

replies.author: @neekMarieM14
replies.text:
Also a code monkey, but for a smaller company. You better believe that when I was a part of a project with fifty-plus people spread over four teams, everyone not on the team currently doing their sprint planning during our massive ESR/planning meetings was doing something else: loading a dishwasher, feeding the baby a bottle (we had some moms who only worked part-time), answering other emails, folding socks, checking in on banking. This included team managers. My own father, a professor of engineering, would be holding remote office hours while playing with the dog. Multitasking during the "boring" part of meetings is normal, even back in the office a couple days a week, we're doing small digital tasks while in these meetings.

It sounds like all the extra hours you are putting in aren't being recognized, and you'd be better off finding a place where the hours will be appreciated or unnecessary, and with better management.

replies.author: @RiskOfBaer
replies.text: @neekMarieM14 First lesson you learn: if you work for a big company and are a low level grunt, you're just a faceless employee who's efforts won't be recognized. You're just a cog in the machine, on your own you're not even able to shift any of their metrics they care about. That's why you see so many people just doing nothing, because they can get away with it. The old 80-20 rule applies here too. About 20% of the people at those big companies do 80% of the work. If you actually want to work hard and profit from it, you need to either start your own business or join another business that is still in the early startup stages when all everybody cares about is working hard and making a difference, and a single person can get a lot of good work done.

replies.author: @theondono
replies.text:
@velenvskaelhas "Big tech is not having problems finding workers, I'm not sure where you pulled that fact from but its simply not true."

Easy, I *work in tech*. Everyone has open positions, a massively overworked crew and too much work ahead. Trying to hire senior engineers is crazy, and salaries have grown quite a bit. I get hit with offers daily, and I have my profile set to "I'm not looking for new positions".

> Also what does the "teach people to code" bubble even mean?

Big Tech has convinced all kinds of governments (states, cities, even small towns) that there's lots of people wanting to code but they just don't have the knowledge. These governments pay subsidies and set up "programming" courses that churn out crappy web developers. 

This has become very profitable for the course givers (because free money) and for big tech (because making the worker pool look larger tends to depress wages), while screwing the "students" (who end up doing things they didn't sign for) and the tax payer (because those courses were worthless anyway).

text: I don't know who you guys are, but I'm glad I found this video. My best friend and I have a chat almost daily about corporate baby sitting. I've worked in the tech industry for about 6 years now and it only took me a year to realize something was terribly wrong. I've worked on several different creative teams doing video production and animation, and the nature of the job means I'm actually doing real work, but only for half the day most of the time (sometimes more, sometimes less). The amount of pointless meetings and committees is mind blowing to me. Everyday feels incredibly pointless. It truly feels like 99% of the people at any given tech company are just working for the sake of working and seeming busy. I can't tell you how many last minute "emergency" requests I've gotten over the years requiring me to work super late or over the weekend for no apparent reason. Or mindless feedback I've gotten from 10 individuals who have no business giving feedback, but feel they must do so to show their worth. I could go on for ages. I remember one time we had a company meeting where this motivational speaker came to speak to us all. He was an Air-force pilot and in an attempt to motivate people to push themselves he introduced us to his catchphrase "Push it up". He has repeat over and over again "Push it up" while pumping our fists in the air. I felt like I was in a cult. It was actually kind of a scary moment. It really is apocalyptic. I'm paid well and now work from home which Is why I have no desire to leave. That leaves me time and money to focus on stuff I actually think matters.

replies.author: @12vscience
replies.text: @wolfskull_wardagger The Bolsheviks destroyed the lives of my ancestors. Queen Catherine the Great of Russia, formerly a German princess, invited Germans to set up farming colonies along the Volga River. Many didn't even learn the Russian language. Russia needed to modernize and better food production was key. For a few hundred years they had a good thing going with some form of property rights. Then, as it was written in my family history, the Bolsheviks asked the Volga River Germans if they wanted to continue their way of life or work on a commune. They of course wanted to continue their way of life and were forced relocated to Siberia because they chose the wrong answer. The Bolsheviks only allowed them to take what they could carry. In a harsh environment, with little material wealth like manufacturing and harvesting tools, there were starvation and weather related deaths. And ironically, Russians starved soon after. Some Volga River Germans were able to escape to their great-great grandparents' homeland of Germany. Those with foresight about the bad times to come on continental Europe migrated mainly to the the plains of the United States where many set up farms. And government welfare wasn't a thing back then.

replies.author: @SoloRenegade
replies.text:
RAT natural evolution has a biological imperative to be lazy (efficient). 

Working hard does not mean a person is not lazy. But working harder than necessary is also a form of working hard that is both unproductive and wasteful.

To survive, life needs to maximize teh use of its available resources to safeguard the species. They will accomplish as much as possible with as little effort as possible. This is why giving people stuff rather than making them earn it creates problems. They are maximizing their outcomes with minimal effort, but if everyone did that, there would be no free crap to hand out to such people.

Laziness is what motivates people to be more efficient, what motivates a farmer to invent the combine and tractor, what motivates a person to invent a washing machine so they can get more work done in teh same amount of time.

But people these days don't understand this. They even invent things that make their lives HARDER. these people are lazy but stupid and inefficient. Lazy people who are smart and efficient is what we want.

That is stress.

replies.author: @warc8us
replies.text:
That's how white collar work goes. I'm an IT Director with 20 years working in offices in many industries. There are days you feel kind of bad for not getting anything done, but they are offset by the days when there isn't enough of you to go around and the pressure is stacked high to fix something or meet a deadline. It balances out. When I was younger I worked on a factory floor and the pressures there are different. That job was about being on time, to the minute, because if you were late that meant the poor guy or girl who was operating your machine for the last 8 hours needs to keep working. Quickly learned how valuable it was to be on time. I worked hard, physically, at that job and left at the end of the night feeling pretty good about the work I put in. I NEVER left that factory job feeling like I didn't put in enough effort. But that's how it goes. That's one of the divides between blue collar and white collar work. In white collar work you need to make your own decisions and keep yourself busy sometimes. People notice it over time, even if they don't notice it day to day or even if they don't confront you about it. Time will tell. If the ladies in this video don't do actual work, they won't advance further than nepotism will allow. For most people, nepotism doesn't carry far.

For anyone who reads this the important thing is to find work you enjoy doing. Sometimes you have to stick it out at a shitty job for a while. Keep going. Pad that resume and every couple years, put yourself out there and get a job offer. Interviewing for jobs is like dating, the correct way to look at it is as a numbers game. Apply often, even if only a small percentage of applications result in interviews. Disregard rejection. Keep trying, stay until you've run the salary/position ladder as far as you can go, then find another job. Ask for more money than you think you deserve. Take what you want an increase it by 5k or 10k, and ask for the bigger number. It's the best way to improve your salary and position. Find a job you enjoy working with people you think are cool.

author: @johnlocke9437
text: I worked at a US tech firm in Sunnyvale for 8 years and I can confirm that this is pretty accurate. At first I thought I'd hit the jackpot being handsomely paid to do very little but after a while the lack of personal achievement eats away at your soul and leaves you hollow. I left after it became abundantly clear that doing something was irrelevant as long as you were saying the right thing. Missing deadlines paled in comparison to having pronouns in your intranet bio. The whole thing was a facade for virtue and the business itself was crumbling behind the scenes. It wasn't like that at the start but the speed at which this mindset became dominant was staggering.

replies.author: @umiluv
replies.text: Indeed.  I audited tech companies in Silicon Valley and worked in a tech company in W LA and yes, it was very much like this.  Except I was one of the people actually busting my hump to do work.  It becomes too much work for those who work and are forced to stay in the office vs the weirdos who willingly live at work 24/7.  It‚Äôs a weird culture.

Some projects I would spend months on, and then never get used after they changed plans. But they were so rich that they didn't care about the lost productivity.

At first, you are also just happy to get paid, but then the feeling of not producing anything tangible for that money does indeed hollow you out.

Plus, half the company (mostly young girls, who were daughters of the bosses' important business contacts) seemed to do literally nothing aside from eat and gossip.

And yes, the company was hemorrhaging money too, but its parent company was worth tens of billions of dollars and thus nobody cared. My colleague even got paid for three months after leaving, as they repeatedly forgot to remove him from the payroll. Madness.

author: @captainphoenix
text:
I own a landscaping company. I've been in the landscaping industry for 23 years. I do WAY LESS manual labor than I ever have, now that I have people working for me.
Here was my Friday: Move wheelbarrow after wheelbarrow of traprock (a gravel stone) to the tune of three cubic yards of material into an excavation site, level, hand pack, then run a 200 lb plate compactor over the area, load all of the equipment into the back of the truck, and then unload at the end of the day. It was 85 degrees with zero shade where we were working, and the humidity was so high the heat index peaked at 97. We took _our_ water (from the tap) break at 2:00 pm after having got _to the job site_ at 8:30 am, because we were so physically exhausted we were about to throw up. And this was nowhere near the hardest day I've ever had, nor the most dangerous (climbing trees with a chainsaw comes to mind), nor the longest, nor the most physically exhausting.
After work, I clogged up my shower drain, ate some leftover chicken, and went to bed, because 10 hours of back-breaking manual labor in your 30s will tend to do that to you.
I invite this woman to spend 30 minutes on the job with us some time. And then hear her thoughts on "women's representation" in an industry that's at least 97% men.

replies.author: @rachelclark6393
replies.text: I genuinely think this sort of job agrees with me more than office work does, but I'd be leery of trying to get into this kind of work because it s questionable whether I'd be able to keep up physically.  It's not that I couldn't do the work, but the pace I'd need to work at for my own physical well-being would almost certainly be slower than the men on the crew - and how awful to be part of a crew and then be the millstone.  It's not that I have nothing to offer - I'm good at outdoor things, I'm good with my hands, I'm not afraid of hard work, etc.  But the differences between doing those things at home and doing them professionally on a crew are real.  And there's also the question of what the work will do to me body.  For women, we also have to ask think if we intend to ever have a child and if your body will be in a good enough condition to do so?  I think there's a discussion to be had about women doing jobs men traditionally do.  If nothing else,  world wars have proven its possible.  But I think we need a bit more reality in the conversation.

author: @Ariescz
text:
I like to call this "work without measurable result", meaning you are just in the office, doing not much at all, but still get paid. Covers stuff like bureaucrats, secretaries, social media people, it support, etc.

Stark contrast from "actual work" in tech, like programming, where you still need to complete a project within a deadline

replies.author: @InternetAudiocrat
replies.text: I'm really not sure how you can lump "IT Support" in there unless you genuinely don't understand what support does in a given day. There are definitely some cushy support jobs, but for the most part IT Support is highly busy and very stressful in a given day. Most days you end up working tickets nearly non-stop on top of answering phone calls constantly and getting yelled at for shit you didn't break and are desperately trying to fix for ungrateful idiots. I'm not pretending like I work physically hard like laborers or food service, but it certainly isn't "work without measurable result" in any way. The number of users who work in industries like manufacturing and accounting, who would get nothing done without the ability to ring support and have us solve their problems, might seriously shock you.

replies.author: @Joogoo96
replies.text: @InternetAudiocrat I work IT Store Support, and you've got it spot on.

replies.author: @Ariescz
replies.text:
@InternetAudiocrat I worked IT support for my local ISP several years back. When everything was working (which was like 75% of my time there), I had nothing to to, and it was rather dull (because the office was relatively new, and I was usually alone there, nothing to distract myself).

I work with IT support people now, and again, they tend to not be the busiest people in the office (though I do respect them for being able to calm the clients down, because I would have immense desire to punch them through the screen)

Several of my MMO guildmates are working IT support (not sure exactly what field or how high up in the chain), and let's just say they have plenty of time to grind and farm stuff.

Of course, when stuff breaks down, then yes, you are working like crazy. But it tends to be in infrequent bursts, from my experience (which admittedly could have been less of the "grunt" level IT support of fixing printers)

author: @kaisokusekkendou1498
text:
As a data analyst, I find that I also have so many meetings sometimes, that they can take up almost my whole day.

Which is why I end up only half pay attention to the meeting and spend my time working on the actual things I need to work on.

I could not imagine how anything would get done if I treated my work day like she does.

And I absolutely can't blame her. It's the work environment fostered by management.
My own office (at least the call centre department), had been backsliding over the last 15 years.

It started with wearing "proper business attire", and you were sent home if you didn't have a buttoned shirt.
With each management change it degraded. It changed to casual wear anytime. Then motivation changed from "get a dollar a call" to "win moves for the communal Risk game" to "popcorn machine and nerf gun games during breaks"... to "here's the quiet room" (which makes more sense in context of an open floor with hundreds of people talking to customers, but still)... to "here's the sandbox and coloring books". I am NOT being hyperbolic, this was literally what happened.

The fact that the job incited people to want to weep in a quiet room to destress from being screamed at, or degrade to infant behavior to escape that stress, should be quite telling of the kind of job it was becoming.

This all comes from management.
Yes the "dress code" guy was kind of harsh, but we worked like it was an adult environment. There were adult expectations, and you found people were able to handle the adult customers with adult concerns and adult stress far more appropriately.

text:
I am SO glad my company is headed by an old, bull-headed man with a strict sense of "business only. We will take care of you, but we will not baby you."
Business casual is the requirement, so slacks or nice jeans and a polo are the absolute most casual you can be. Every morning at 10 AM we have a meeting ON TEAMS to go over our goals for the day, and things don't drag on. We have a cafeteria, but it has a "Text you when your food's done" feature to discourage waiting until your food's done, so you can just go back to your desk and work. You are expected to get a set amount done every day, doesn't matter how it's done.

author: @padraig6200
text:
9:39 in Australia in construction and mining we get whats called an RDO (Rostered Day Off).
This is a day, usually once a month, that you get as a paid day off though they take 2hrs a week out of your paycheck in order to give you that 8hrs pay.
The plus side is that if you decide to work that day you automatically start your shift on 1.5x pay and youll be on 2x for the majority of your shift.

In my first company over there we took the last Monday off the month off or if there was already a long weekend in the month we would've taken it then for the extra long holiday. I usually worked every RDO but it was nice to have the option of a day off to chill out and not miss any pay

replies.author: @Mocha.
replies.text: The sad thing being a teacher is you can see the disconnect in class. One part of your class will end up "working" like this person, while the other part of your class will end up doing the work to pay for the luxuries of these busy bodies. The only determining factor being family background and nepotism. I have seen absolute simpletons being coaxed through fullbright scholarships to do law or business at Oxbridge while some of the smartest kids went on to do disciplines like math and physics at some no-name because they couldn't get those prestigious scholarships or couldn't afford a big name university. Guess who has to work tooth and nail and who gets to be a busy-body doing no actual work.
